div1.p: Maps are Made More Accurate, Old System of Reproducing the World on a Flat Surface Caused Distortions in Distances--Improvement Is an Aid to Commerce [From the Henry Rose Carter Papers]

div1.head: Newspaper clipping fragment, The New York Times, October 23, 1927
div1.p:
Old System of Reproducing the World on a Flat
Surface Caused Distortions in Distances--
Improvement Is an Aid to Commerce

A NEW form of world map that
overcomes the distortion in-
herent in those maps hitherto
commonly in use is being introduced
by the Department of Commerce. It
is called the “Equal Area World
Map,” and has been prepared by the
Bureau of Foreign and Domestic
Commerce in cooperation with the
Coast and Geodetic Survey.

The fault in the old maps was
that when the curved surface of the
earth was made to appear flat, dis-
tances had to be altered to make the
map appear continuous. The usual
flat map, for example, makes the
United States appear almost twice as
large as Brazil, although Brazil is
actually the larger. In approximate
terms each of these countries em-
braces an area similar to that of
Europe. On some old maps Europe
appears twice as large as the United
States and about four times as large
as Brazil. The same distortion ap-
pears as to Africa, which looks
smaller than North America, al-
though 50 per cent. larger in actual
square mileage.

The Mercator projection, with
which maps have been made for
more than 300 years, gives rise to
the distortion. Apt illustration is
afforded by attempting to spread out
an orange peel on a flat surface. The
peel must be torn and split in many
places before it will lie flat, leaving
ragged and irregular gaps. The same
thing happens when the map-maker
undertakes to “flatten” the globe to
fit the Mercator projection. In the
case of the map the gaps are filled
with fictitious areas of land and
water. The result is a condition of
gross exaggeration progressively in-
creasing toward the North and South
Poles. The only point at which the
map is true to scale is at the equa-
tor. A square inch of the map in
equatorial latitude represents several
times as much actual territory as a
square inch in Alaska or northern
Europe.

With the growth of American in-
terest in world commerce and the
closer contact between the United
States and foreign nations, the
United States Department of Com-
merce has realized the disadvantage
of using a map based on the old
Mercator projection for the presenta-
tion of trade and statistical facts.
The new map presents every place,
land or sea, in its correct geographic
relationship as to area and distances
in comparison with all other portions
of the map. In brief terms it may
be stated that each square inch on
the new map stands for the same
number of square miles as a similar
space in any other region of the
world.

The new map is said to be a dis-
tinct innovation in chart making, af-
fording marked contrast with the
familiar maps based on the Mercator
projection. In the Mercator type the
parallels of latitude and meridians of
longitude are at right angles. On
the new map all the parallels run
horizontally in line with the Equator
and all east and west distances along
parallels are true, permitting the
comparison of all distances east and
west. At no place does he obtain
the distorted picture presented on
the Mercator map.

For purposes of construction, and
in order to offer the best possible
shape, each continent on the new
map has been centred on a mid-
meridian vertical to the Equator.
Along each of these meridians all dis-
tances are true to scale, and may be
given accurate measurement in ac-
cordance with the linear scale given
on the map. The greatest variations
are where the meridians depart most
from the vertical, but this occurs in
remote ocean areas which are little
traveled. For all practical purposes
distances may be estimated with a
fair degree of accuracy at all points
on the map. This is impossible on
the Mercator projection, since on it
a scale can be used at no place but
along the line of the Equator.

The equal-area map is divided into
three strange-looking lobes, as af-
fording the best presentation of the
land areas of the world. The
“blanks” between lobes represent
the large areas which the Mercator
map-maker fills in with artificial
territory. The innovation enables
the new map to picture continents in
their true shapes and sizes.

A glimpse of the new map along-
side the the accepted Mercator type
affords interesting contrasts. On the
older map North America appears to
have far greater area than its sister
continent on the south. The actual
figures show that the area of North
America is 8,049,000 square miles,
while that of South America is
7,018,000, a disparity much less than
that indicated by the Mercator map.
The new projection shows the two
continents in true proportion.

Another pronounced exaggeration
is manifest in connection with
Greenland. On the Mercator map
this territory appears larger than the
whole South American Continent.
On the new projection Greenland
shrinks to proper proportions--
about one-tenth the size of South
America. The exaggeration of Mer-
cator with reference to Greenland is
due to the island's nearness to the
Pole, where the “gaps” filled in by
the chart maker reach their great-
est extent. Alaska affords similar
evidence of distortion when com-
pared with Bolivia. The two are of
about the same area, but on the
Mercator projection Alaska appears
several times larger.

The value of an equal-area world
map for statistical and trade pur-
poses is obvious. In planning a sales
campaign abroad the American ex-
porter is concerned with the relative
extent of the areas involved in for-
eign marketing. During conferences
the trade executive equipped with a
true map may easily estimate dis-
tances between his sales centres, to-
gether with the amount of territory
each of his men will serve. A glance
at the truly proportioned map shows
him the futility of assigning one
man a great extent of territory on
the African coast, or the unneces-
sary duplication involved in placing
several men close together in thickly
populated areas, where travel is a
simple matter.

The new map has especial value in
connection with the distribution of
the world's population. Because of
the equal-area scale this map makes
it possible to present a true picture
of density throughout the world,
since dots can be placed in their
true locations with reference to one
another. On the Mercator base such
truthful presentation is out of the
question, for the reason that most
of the world's population is located
at considerable distances north of
the Equator, where exaggerations in
area become pronounced. In conse-
quence the Mercator base greatly
understates the density of peopled
areas.

Experienced exporters know that
relative density of population is a
vital factor in foreign distribution
of merchandise. When the execu-
tive sees trade facts properly set
forth on a world map he learns much
that is worth knowing. This is true
of business data of all sorts. There
